conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the rods and the induced electromotive force (EMF) due to the motion of the rods in the magnetic field.

premise: The induced EMF in rod \(a\) is given by: \[ \mathcal{E}_a = B L v_a \] where \(B = 0.2 \, \text{T}\), \(L = 0.5 \, \text{m}\), and \(v_a = 1.0 \, \text{m/s}\).
The total resistance in the circuit is \(2R = 0.2 \, \Omega\). The current \(I\) in the circuit is: \[ I = \frac{\mathcal{E}_a}{2R} = \frac{0.1}{0.2} \]
The force on rod \(b\) due to the magnetic field is: \[ F_b = B I L = 0.2 \times 0.5 \times 0.5 \]

The net force on rod \(b\) is the difference between the magnetic force and the component of gravitational force along the incline: \[ F_{\text{net}, b} = F_b - m_b g \sin \theta \] where \(m_b = 0.1 \, \text{kg}\) and \(\theta = 30^\circ\).
The acceleration \(a_b\) of rod \(b\) is: \[ a_b = \frac{F_{\text{net}, b}}{m_b} = \frac{-0.45}{0.1} \]
Since the rods are in contact and move together, the velocity of rod \(b\) is the same as the velocity of rod \(a\):
